pageTitle: AV-Test.Org Releases Real-World Malware Protection Report
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {28754=Norton Internet Security 2010 scored highest at malware detection, at 98.0 percent. Even the least successful of the twelve, Trend Micro Internet Security 2010, detected 83.3 percent. Of course, detecting a threat doesn't always mean successfully preventing the attack. The top scorer for actual malware blocking (the more important test) was PC Tools Internet Security 2010, at 94.8 percent. CA Internet Security 2010 brought up the rear with 73.5 percent. Here are the full results:, 38926=The second chart, showing successful blocking of threats, is naturally the more important of the two; detection without successful blocking isn't so useful. This kind of dynamic testing is the wave of the future. It's hard to do, but it's the only way to really evaluate a product's ability to protect against malware. [Edited on 12/22/2009 at the request of AV-Test.org to clarify that the blocking test is the most important and that "false alarms" represent good programs detected as malware. -njr]}
textBeforeTable: MALWARE BLOCKING RATES AND BLOCKED GOOD PROGRAMS (FALSE ALARMS) few 83.3%  Trend Micro Internet Security 2010 few 84.3%  BitDefender Internet Security 2010 almost none 85.8%  F-Secure Internet Security 2010 few 86.7%  CA Internet Security 2010 few 87.2%  McAfee Internet Security 2010 many 87.7%  Avira Premium Security Suite 9.0 almost none 90.0%  Panda Internet Security 2010 many 90.0%  G Data Internet Security 2010 few 92.2%  AVG Internet Security 9.0 almost none 95.8%  PC Tools Internet Security 2010 few 97.5%  Kaspersky Internet Security 2010 almost none 98.0%  Symantec Norton Internet Security 2010 False Alarms
textAfterTable: The second chart, showing successful blocking of threats, is naturally the more important of the two; detection without successful blocking isn't so useful. This kind of dynamic testing is the wave of the future. It's hard to do, but it's the only way to really evaluate a product's ability to protect against malware. [Edited on 12/22/2009 at the request of AV-Test.org to clarify that the blocking test is the most important and that "false alarms" represent good programs detected as malware. -njr] Categories: Security Software, Malware Tags: anti-malware, security suite, antispyware
